context: The analytical process and determination of values used for δ13C were those described in Kaown et al. (2014a) and Hunkeler and Aravena (2000). For the carbon isotope analysis, 10 representative wells were selected from the monitoring wells situated between the source zone and the stream. The minimum concentrations of TCE in the carbon isotope analysis were approximately 30μg/L. The δ13C values of TCE (δ13CTCE) were then reported relative to Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite (δ13CVPDB) (Coplen, 1996), with an analytical precision of ±0.3‰ using the delta notation given by δ13C=(R/R std −1)1000 (‰); here R and Rstd are the isotope ratios of the sample and the δ13CVPDB standard, respectively.Microbial community analysis Water samples (20L each) were collected around the stream for the microbial community analysis. Samples were then filtered using a 0.22-μm filter (Millipore, Bedford, MA, USA), after which the filters were exfoliated using distilled water and subjected to total DNA extraction using a DNeasy Plant Mini Kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA) (Nübel et al., 1997). Amplification was carried out using a C1000 Touch thermal cycler (BioRad, Hercules, CA, USA) in a final volume of 50μL, using 10× Taq buffer dNTP mixture (Takara, Shiga, Japan). The amplification condition was the same as that given in Hur et al. (2013).
